biogHist.abstract: The Catholic Family Welfare Bureau (CFWB) was established on 2 June 1970 as a part-time social work service of the Catholic Archdiocese of Perth, with a focus on children in Catholic institutions. In June 1977 it became part of Centrecare.
biogHist.p: The Catholic Family Welfare Bureau (CFWB) was established as a part-time agency of the Catholic Archdiocese of Perth in June 1970. It had an initial focus on overseeing applications for institutional care, with the following priorities:

list.item: Assessing private (non-ward) applications and offering alternatives to placement if relevant
Arranging Social Worker contact with families of children who were not placed
Arranging Social Worker contact with families of children were were placed
Arranging Social Worker consultation with the staff at institutions where children were placed
Integrating the work of volunteer groups at institutions, including after-care groups
Consultative work with institution staff around policies and operations

biogHist.p: According to Coldrey in his history of Clontarf (The Scheme p.174), the CFWB had an immediate impact on Clontarf's admission policies with 'ordinary country boarders and local day boys' no longer being admitted.
In June 1977 the CFWB became part of Centrecare.

cpfRelation.relationEntry: Catholic Episcopal Migration and Welfare Association [CEMWA] (1947? - 1970)

descriptiveNote.p: The Catholic Family Welfare Bureau took over the welfare function of the CEMWA but did not have any major formal role in dealing with former child migrants, except occasionally providing Baptismal certificates for marriages.
The Catholic Family Welfare Bureau was an agency of the Catholic Archdiocese of Perth.
It has been claimed in a history of Clontarf that the Catholic Family Welfare Bureau was a factor in a decline of country boarders and day students being enrolled at Clontarf.

cpfRelation.relationEntry: Maria Harries interviewed by Christine Choo in the Forgotten Australians and Former Child Migrants oral history project (2011)

descriptiveNote.p: Maria Harries was one of the first group of Social Workers employed by the Catholic Family Welfare Bureau on a part-time basis to set up the new service.
